title: 106_hr3545
content: The Act may be cited as the "IDEA Full Funding Act of 2000". The Congress acknowledges the importance of providing equal education opportunities for children with disabilities under the 14th Amendment. It recognizes the need for federal assistance to improve educational outcomes and ensure equal protection of the law. The excess cost of educating a child with a disability is estimated to be 40% higher than the national average per pupil expenditure. Congress has committed to supporting these efforts under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The Federal Government has committed to contributing up to 40 percent of the national average per pupil expenditure for educating children with disabilities. However, it has never contributed more than 12.6 percent of the maximum state grant allocation under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The purpose of this Act is to achieve the Federal Government's goal of providing 40 percent of the national average per pupil expenditure for educating all children with disabilities by 2010. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Authorization of appropriations for the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is outlined, with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 2001 to 2010 and subsequent years as needed. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act authorizes increasing amounts of appropriations from $85,000,000 in fiscal year 2001 to $130,000,000 in fiscal year 2010. Technical and related assistance provisions are also amended. Authorization of appropriations for sections 681 through 685 increases from $65,000,000 in fiscal year 2001 to $110,000,000 in fiscal year 2010.
